explanation:
For each symbol: 
- OS_CHECK_POINTER: macro called at function start; macro expansion could contain loops or side-effects that affect the well-formedness of any for loop in this function or called functions.
- OS_ObjectIdGetById: the function obtains the object token; its implementation may contain for-loops or modify objects used as loop counters/flags in other routines called here.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit: called by OS_ObjectIdGetById; needed to inspect for any loops or side-effects that would be part of the target function's execution.
- OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex: used in object-id processing; may contain loops or indexing logic relevant to verifying loop-counter usage and modifications.
- OS_ObjectIdConvertToken: converts id to token; could contain loops/side-effects that affect loop analysis.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: used on failure paths in ObjectIdGetById; include to cover all control-flow that could include loops or modify objects used as loop counters.
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: macro used to obtain record/stream; macro expansion may call indexing helpers or introduce loops/side-effects important for the rule.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: commonly used by OBJECT_TABLE_GET and by called impl functions; may contain loops or perform modifications to global objects that could violate the rule.
- OS_global_stream_table: global array accessed via OBJECT_TABLE_GET; its indexing and contents influence whether called routines modify objects used as loop counters.
- OS_stream_table: global used to get the stream record; its structure and accessors may contain loops or cause side-effects relevant to the analysis.
- OS_stream_internal_record_t: structure type for stream; needed to know which fields (e.g., stream_state, stream_name) may be modified by called functions and whether those are used as loop counters/flags.
- OS_common_record_t: structure type for record; needed to see whether name_entry or other fields are modified in called routines that could affect loop-counter rules.
- OS_SocketDomain_INVALID: value tested in function; include to see if macros/enum definitions involve side-effects or if related code paths contain loops.
- OS_STREAM_STATE_BOUND: flag used in stream_state tests and setting; include to see if related macros/functions manipulate these flags in ways that affect loop control.
- OS_STREAM_STATE_CONNECTED: as above, used in state test; include to determine whether flag usage intersects with loops in called code.
- OS_SocketBindAddress_Impl: the implementation called to perform the actual bind; must be inspected for any for-loops (their counters, side-effects, modification of external objects) because called functions' bodies are part of loop-body behaviour per the rule.
- OS_CreateSocketName: called on success; it may contain loops (e.g., string formatting, name lookup) or modify objects used elsewhere; its internals are required for a complete for-loop compliance check.
- OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl: called by CreateSocketName; include because it may contain loops or modify external state relevant to for-loop rules.
- OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl: called by CreateSocketName; include to inspect for loops/side-effects.
- OS_strnlen: used by CreateSocketName; standard library/string helpers can contain loops; include to ensure any loop there is considered (or its absence confirmed).
- OS_ObjectIdRelease: releases token at end; its implementation could include loops or modify global objects that interact with any for-loop counters or flags.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish: called by ObjectIdRelease; include to inspect potential loops/side-effects in release/finish paths.

These symbols together cover the macros, direct callees, helper routines and global/state data that could contain for-loops or perform side-effects relevant to determining whether any for statements executed in the target function (directly or via called functions) are well-formed under the MISRA rule.
